title-group.article-title: Rare Surgical Management of Renal Lymphangiectasia: Marsupialization Into Peritoneal Cavity

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2025 The Author(s). Clinical Case Reports published by John Wiley & Sons Ltd.

license.license-p: This is an open access article under the terms of the http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ License, which permits use and distribution in any medium, provided the original work is properly cited, the use is non‐commercial and no modifications or adaptations are made.

abstract.title: ABSTRACT
abstract.p: Renal lymphangiectasia is a rare condition resulting from miscommunication between renal and retroperitoneal lymphatic ducts, causing ductal dilatation and lymphatic fluid collection. In this report, we present this condition and highlight an uncommon management approach involving cyst marsupialization. A 24‐year‐old female presented with flank pain and lumbar tenderness. Ultrasonography revealed a fluid collection, further evaluated by contrast‐enhanced CT, which provided additional details and ruled out urine as the source. Fluid analysis confirmed its lymphatic origin, leading to a diagnosis of renal lymphangiectasia. The condition was managed with marsupialization into the peritoneal cavity. At a one‐year follow‐up, the patient's symptoms had resolved, and ultrasonography showed that the kidney was decompressed with no fluid collection. This case of renal lymphangiectasia underscores its diagnostic challenges and sheds light on the rarely reported marsupialization technique, demonstrating its potential effectiveness and contributing to the growing literature on this rare condition.

p.mixed-citation: I.Barghouth, Q.Hassan, A.Saad, A.Obied, and D.Alhomsi, “Rare Surgical Management of Renal Lymphangiectasia: Marsupialization Into Peritoneal Cavity,” Clinical Case Reports13, no. 10 (2025): e71025, 10.1002/ccr3.71025.

fn.p: Funding: The authors received no specific funding for this work.

list-item.p: This case highlights the diagnostic challenge of renal lymphangiectasia due to its nonspecific symptoms, emphasizing the need for a thorough clinical, radiological, and pathological correlation to avoid misdiagnosis.

Additionally, it demonstrates that marsupialization—an underreported but effective approach—can be a viable alternative to percutaneous drainage or nephrectomy in select cases, offering symptom relief while preserving renal function.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Lymphangiectasia, also known as lymphangioma or lymphangiomatosis, is a benign condition caused by abnormal connections between the lymphatic vessels, resulting in impaired lymphatic drainage and subsequent cystic dilatation of the lymphatic channels [1, 2]. It primarily affects the head and neck regions (approximately 70% of cases), followed by the chest and axillary regions (20%–25%). Internal organ involvement is observed in only about 5% of cases, with renal involvement being very rare [3, 4].

Renal lymphangiectasia is a rare condition, with limited data on its cause, incidence, and clinical progression, primarily derived from case reports and series [4, 5]. It can affect one or both kidneys, appear in both children and adults, and show no gender predilection [3, 6]. It likely results from miscommunication between renal and retroperitoneal lymphatic ducts, leading to ductal dilation and cyst formation in the perirenal, peripelvic, or intrarenal regions. This resemblance to more common cystic lesions can lead to misdiagnosis, requiring different treatment approaches [4, 5, 7].

In this report, we present the first documented case of renal lymphangiectasia in Syria, contributing to the existing literature on this rare condition. This case also highlights an uncommon management approach, utilizing cyst marsupialization into the peritoneal cavity. This work has been reported in line with the CARE Guidelines [8].

sec.title: Case History and Examination
sec.p: A 24‐year‐old female presented to the urology clinic with left flank pain, accompanied by bilateral flank discomfort. She denied symptoms of fever, hematuria, or bladder or bowel complaints. Her medical history is significant for celiac disease, with no additional personal or family medical history, nor any history of trauma. She is a non‐smoker and does not consume alcohol. Physical examination indicated tenderness in both lumbar regions but was otherwise normal.

sec.title: Differential Diagnosis and Investigations
sec.p: Laboratories were unremarkable. Abdominal and pelvic ultrasonography revealed mixed echogenic fluid collection in the perirenal regions, entirely confined to the renal capsules bilaterally, with slight compression of the left kidney. No evidence of stones or hydronephrosis was observed.

A contrast‐enhanced Computed Tomography (CT) scan demonstrated that both kidneys had normal morphology, with no evidence of hydronephrosis or lesions. A moderate perirenal fluid collection surrounded each kidney Figure 1. The left kidney was relatively smaller, with a cystic collection of dense fluid measuring 13 cm lateral to the kidney, displacing it medially. Additional smaller fluid collections were noted superiorly and inferiorly to the left kidney, the largest measuring 2 cm. The absence of contrast accumulation during the excretory phase ruled out a urinoma secondary to a urinary leak.

caption.p: Computed tomography (CT) of the abdomen and pelvis revealed normal kidneys without hydronephrosis. A fluid collection was observed surrounding the kidneys, more prominent on the left side. (A) Axial CT scan. (B) Coronal CT scan.

sec.p: To determine the origin of the fluid, a bilateral percutaneous drain insertion was performed, and 4 L were drained from the left side and 2 L from the right. The fluid was straw‐colored and clear on gross examination. Samples were collected for chemical analysis. The fluid's creatinine levels matched those of serum creatinine, ruling out urine as the source. Additional findings supported a lymphatic origin of the fluid, with 80% lymphocytes, protein levels of 4.2 g/dL, triglycerides (TGA) at 15 mg/dL, and cholesterol at 45 mg/dL.

sec.title: Outcome and Follow‐Up
sec.p: Based on radiological and laboratory findings, a diagnosis of renal lymphangiectasia was established. We managed the left side by marsupializing the malformation into the peritoneal cavity, Figure 2. We made a left flank incision extending through the layers to the retroperitoneum, then isolated the peritoneum from Gerota's fascia, which was notably thick. Incising Gerota's fascia released a quantity of fluid that was subsequently drained. We took a biopsy of Gerota's fascia and marsupialized the remaining margins to the peritoneum. Histopathological analysis revealed fibrosis, congestion, and mixed inflammatory infiltrate (plasma cells, lymphocytes, neutrophils, eosinophils, and hemosiderin‐laden macrophages) consistent with an inflammatory pseudocyst with no signs of malignancy.

caption.p: Intraoperative images demonstrating the surgical procedure. (A) Flank incision exposing the retroperitoneum and thickened Gerota's fascia. (B) Incision of Gerota's fascia with release and drainage of fluid. (C) Suturing of the fascial margins. (D) Marsupialization of the margins to the peritoneum. (E) Illustration of the created anastomosis.

sec.p: At a one‐year follow‐up, the patient's symptoms had resolved. Ultrasonography showed no evidence of fluid collection, and the kidney was decompressed. The right side will be managed using a similar approach.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Renal lymphangiectasia is a rare benign developmental anomaly of the renal lymphatic system, affecting the renal parenchyma, capsule, and perinephric tissue [3, 9]. To date, approximately 110 cases have been documented worldwide, resulting in limited insights into its etiopathogenesis, incidence, prevalence, and clinical course. Most knowledge regarding its clinical manifestations and diagnostic features derives from isolated case reports and small case series [4, 7, 10, 11]. This report presents a case of renal lymphangiectasia, detailing the clinical presentation, diagnostic process, and management strategies, thereby contributing to the limited available literature on this rare condition.

Most reported cases of renal lymphangiectasia involve unilateral disease, with bilateral presentation being much less common [12, 13, 14]. Bilateral involvement is particularly relevant as it may increase the risk of renal impairment, making preservation of renal function a key consideration in management. Our case adds to the limited number of bilateral presentations in the literature and underscores the importance of individualized treatment strategies in such patients.

The clinical presentation of renal lymphangiectasia is highly variable and typically characterized by slow progression, as the condition arises in a relatively safe anatomical region [7]. Many cases are asymptomatic and incidentally identified, particularly those involving small cysts. Common symptoms include abdominal pain, flank pain, hematuria, and hypertension. Larger cysts may result in a sensation of heaviness or discomfort due to compression of adjacent structures [7, 10]. Other symptoms include palpable mass, proteinuria, edema, weight loss, fatigue, and fever. Potential complications encompass cyst rupture, intracystic hemorrhage, superimposed infection, renal vein thrombosis, or renal failure [6, 7, 15]. Our patient presented with flank pain without other symptoms or complications.

Establishing a correlation among clinical, radiological, and pathological findings is essential for confirming the diagnosis of renal lymphangiectasia and excluding other differential diagnoses [5, 7, 16]. Imaging modalities, including ultrasonography, computed tomography (CT) with or without contrast enhancement, and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), are now the preferred diagnostic tools, replacing previously utilized invasive methods such as biopsy and surgical pathology [7]. In certain cases, aspiration and cytological analysis of chylous fluid can provide additional diagnostic confirmation [3, 5, 15]. In this instance, we used contrast‐enhanced CT, combined with the analysis of aspirated fluid, to exclude more common renal lesions, confirm the origin of the fluid, and ultimately establish the diagnosis.

The differential diagnosis varies depending on the patient's age and clinical presentation and includes conditions such as hydronephrosis, polycystic kidney disease, and neoplasms like multilocular cystic nephroma, liposarcoma, leiomyosarcoma, fibrosarcoma, and lymphoma. Other possibilities, such as abscesses and urinomas, should also be considered [3, 15].

Given the rarity of renal lymphangiectasia, no definitive recommendations exist favoring one treatment modality over another. Management is guided by the patient's symptoms, complications, and the extent of involvement [4, 14]. Asymptomatic cases generally do not require treatment, while mild cases can be managed conservatively. Nevertheless, regular follow‐up is advised for these patients due to the potential risk of complications, particularly renal failure and hypertension [10, 17]. In symptomatic cases involving large fluid collections causing compression effects, percutaneous drainage with or without sclerotherapy is a viable option [4, 6]. For severe, refractory, or complicated cases, nephrectomy may be considered [3, 6, 10].

Marsupialization, which involves creating a connection to the peritoneal cavity for fluid drainage, is a rarely used and sparsely described treatment option in the literature [6]. In this report, we highlighted this approach as it may offer a compromise strategy by reducing the relapse risk associated with percutaneous drainage while preserving the kidney, unlike radical interventions. It is particularly suitable for cases with peripheral fluid collections, as demonstrated in our patient. The procedure effectively relieved symptoms, with no recurrence of fluid accumulation on follow‐up imaging, suggesting its potential success when appropriately applied. The bilateral nature of this case further supported our choice of a kidney‐preserving approach, as nephrectomy would carry higher long‐term risks of renal dysfunction.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This case of renal lymphangiectasia underscores the diagnostic challenges posed by its nonspecific symptoms, which can lead to misdiagnosis as other renal conditions. Furthermore, it sheds light on the rarely reported marsupialization technique, indicating its potential effectiveness when used appropriately, and contributes to the expanding body of literature on this rare disease.

sec.title: Author Contributions
sec.p: Ibrahim Barghouth: project administration. Qussai Hassan: project administration. Anas Saad: data curation. Amjad Obied: methodology, writing – review and editing. Dima Alhomsi: methodology, writing – original draft.

sec.title: Ethics Statement
sec.p: The authors have nothing to report.

sec.title: Consent
sec.p: Written informed consent was obtained from the patient for publication of this case report and accompanying images. A copy of the written consent is available upon reasonable request.

sec.title: Conflicts of Interest
sec.p: The authors declare no conflicts of interest.

ack.title: Acknowledgments
ack.p: The authors would like to thank the patient for her cooperation.

sec.title: Data Availability Statement
sec.p: Data related to this case report are available upon reasonable request.
